   71 y/o man with PSC complicated by cirrhosis with known esophageal
   varices presenting with melanic stools and hct drop from esophageal
   variceal bleed s/p banding on [**1-3**] who now is transferred back to the
   ICU in setting of hematemesis.
   .
   # GI bleeding: EGD performed on initial transfer to [**Hospital1 54**] on [**1-3**]
   which showed esophageal varices with cherry red spots (stigmata of
   recent bleeding) over varices. Two varices were banded during that
   initial EGD.  Now s/p repeat EGD upon tx back to ICU with blood seen in
   stomach, but no additional active bleeding noted; varices banded
   again.  Pre bleed, hct was 28.8 and is 27.4 this morning after 2 units
   prbs
   - s/p 2 units FFP for INR 2.3 and 2 units prbcs
   - give additional unit prbcs now
   - repeating hct now
   - Octreotide bolus with 100mcg now then octreotide gtt
   - Protonix gtt
   - Sucralfate 1 gm PO QID for 14 days
   - Has been off Nadolol, diuretics in setting of BPs high 80s-90s
   - 4 20g pivs
   - Already being treated for SBP so no need for proph
   .
   # Hypotension:  It appears that SBPs have been running consistently
   80s-90s while in house and this appears to be his baseline when
   reviewing old OMR notes.  Transiently dipped to 70s on the floor in the
   setting of hemoptysis and, thus, likely represents hypotension in the
   setting of active bleeding.  Of note, however, he has had persistent
   leukocytosis and is being treated with broad spectrum abx for SBP so
   infection is possible contributor.  Lactate elevated to 3.5 on
   presentation to the ICU and ? in setting of hypoperfusion d/t
   underlying infection (lactate previously normal even in the setting of
   his liver disease); has since normalized.  Currently on presentation to
   the ICU, SBPs are stable in the 80s and he is not tachycardic.  No EKG
   changes and CEs negative so as not to suggest underlying cardiogenic
   etiology.
   - Management of UGIB as above
   - Transfusing now
   - Treating underlying infection while awaiting final cx data; on
   meropenem, vancomycin, fluconazole
   - f/u outstanding culture data
   - sending UA/cx, blood cultures, repeat stool
   - Trend lactate
   .
   # Peritonitis: Diagnosed [**2185-1-5**], patient was on Cipro ppx as
   outpatient and recently increased dose due to recent bleed. Placed on
   Aztreonam [**2176**] mg IV Q8H 5 days (Day 1 [**2185-1-5**] - [**2185-1-10**]).  WBC count
   kept rising despite aztreonam/fluconazole, leading to repeat tap [**1-10**]-
   SBP w GNR. Started on Vanc/[**Last Name (un) **] (aztreonam d/c'd) [**1-11**].  Given appears
   polymicrobial ? truly SBP vs. secondary seeding.  Has diffuse abdominal
   discomfort, but not focal pain nor rebound/guarding to suggest acute
   abdominal process.  Cholangiogram without biliary obstruction/leak
   (perc tube pulled [**1-10**]).  Does have left inguinal hernia, but without
   evidence of strangulation/incarceration.   Given concern for possible
   secondary seeding from underlying intraabdominal process will obtain
   RUQ U/S to assess for e/o obstructive/ascending cholangitis (t.bili up
   slightly from yesterday, AP stable).  Will also check CT abd/pelvis
   (without IV contrast, with oral contrast given UOP has dropped off and
   want to see where renal function will settle out).
   - Cont Vanc/[**Last Name (un) **]/fluconazole (fluc started [**1-5**], vanco/[**Last Name (un) 430**] started
   [**1-11**])
   - Monitor LFTs to assess for rising t.bili and concern for possible
   cholangitis given h/o recurrent episodes requiring perc drain placement
   - Repeat tap after 5d to confirm SBP eradication.
   - Received day 3 albumin (1g/kg)
   - Plan for bactrim for ppx following tx.
   - Monitor abdominal exam
   - Pursue abdominal imaging/[**Doctor First Name 458**] consult if abdominal exam at all
   concerning
   .
   # Metabolic acidosis:  Non anion gap.  Lactate was elevated on
   transfer, but normalized this am and, again, non AG met acidosis.  He
   is on standing lactulose and suspect this is in the setting of ongoing
   diarrhea.  Patient did not have h/o encephalopathy prior to last
   discharge (discharged [**12-31**]) at which time he had some mental status
   changes.  Although during that admission, asterixis was never noted,
   there was concern for hepatic encephalopathy so he was started on
   lactulose with perhaps some improvement in MS per d/c summary.  In
   review of his labs, it appears that thereafter his bicarb fell which
   further suggests this is in the setting of diarrhea.  He is again
   without asterixis and is currently alert and oriented x3 so ?
   previously lethargic in setting of infection, meds.
   - continue to monitor chem7/bicarb
   - hold lactulose if continues to fall with close monitoring of mental
   status
   .
   # Leukocytosis: Persistently elevated to nearly 20K range.  Only clear
   source at this point is peritoneal fluid and as above, ? SBP vs.
   secondary seeding although no clear acute intraabdominal process at
   this time. CXR [**1-7**] showed low lung volume and probable small pleural
   effusions, not repeated since and he is without pulmonary symptoms to
   suggest as source.  Did hear soft systolic murmur on exam which is
   noted in old OMR notes so not new and TTE without e/o veg.  Blood and
   urine cultures have shown no growth.  He does have diarrhea, but is on
   lactulose; c. diff negative x1 on [**1-9**].
   - Treating peritonitis as above
   - Awaiting blood, urine cultures, c. diff
   - continue antibiotic coverage as above
   .
   # PSC with cirrhosis: On liver transplant list.   Complicated by
   ascites, portal gastropathy, and SBP. No clear history of
   encephalopathy as discussed above.
   - PTC drain removed [**1-10**]
   - Continue to trend LFTs - check for complications of PTC removal.
   - ursodiol [**Hospital1 **]
   - lactulose 30 mg daily  (may hold if met acidosis persists/worsens)
   - hold spironolactone/lasix in setting of hyponatremia/low BP
   .
   # Strictures: Pull back cholangiography on [**1-10**] demonstrated no
   obstruction. PTC drain removed by IR [**2185-1-10**].
   - Follow LFTs
   .
   # Esophagitis: Biopsy from EGD [**2184-12-28**] biopsy grew [**First Name5 (NamePattern1) **] [**Last Name (NamePattern1) 1656**].
   Unclear etiology. Fluconazole 200 mg qd for 14 days (Day 1 [**2185-1-5**]).
   If symptoms reoccur treat with Vori.
   - Negative fungal cultures
   .
   # Hyponatremia: Per floor team, improved with holding diuretics and
   fluid challenge therefore thought to be most likely hypovolemic
   hyponatremia.  Again improved slightly after receiving NS.
   - f/u urine lytes
   .
   # Ulcerative colitis: Continue outpatient Mesalamine.
   .
   # CAD s/p CABG: Continue Statin. Holding ASA and BB in setting of
   bleed.
   .
   # Hyperlipidemia:  Continue outpatient dose statin.
   .
   # Depression/ADHD: Continue sertraline. Hold Ritalin as needed.
   .
   ICU Care
   Nutrition: NPO for now except meds and may advance to clears in pm if
   no further bleeding.  Calorie counts showed inadequate caloric intake
   and plan was for post pyloric dobhoff to be placed [**1-12**].
   - will need post-pyloric dobhoff once GIB stabilizes
   Lines:
   20 Gauge - [**2185-1-11**] 11:37 PM
   18 Gauge - [**2185-1-11**] 11:38 PM
   Prophylaxis:
   DVT:   Pneumoboots.
   Stress ulcer:   On IV PPI currently.
   Communication:  With patient and wife, [**Name (NI) 7031**] [**Telephone/Fax (3) **]
   [**Name2 (NI) 66**] status:  FULL, confirmed with patient.
   Disposition:  ICU level of care pending hct and HD stability.

The patient is a 71-year-old man with a history of PSC complicated by cirrhosis, esophageal varices, and known bleeding. He presented with melanic stools and a drop in hemoglobin level following a bleeding episode. He was transferred to the ICU for further management.

Current vital signs:

* Temperature: 37.2°C (98.9°F)
* Heart rate: 101 beats per minute (bpm)
* Blood pressure: 105/55 mmHg
* Respiratory rate: 21 breaths per minute
* Oxygen saturation: 96%

Physical examination:

* General appearance: Thin
* Eyes/conjunctiva: PERRL, + scleral icterus
* Cardiovascular: Regular, systolic murmur heard best at the left upper sternal border
* Peripheral vascular: Right radial pulse present, left radial pulse present, right digital pulse present, left digital pulse present
* Respiratory/chest: Symmetric expansion, clear breath sounds anteriorly, crackles in the lateral lung fields
* Abdominal: Soft, bowel sounds present, distended, tender to palpation diffusely
* Extremities: Right: 2+, left: 2+
* Skin: Jaundiced
* Neurologic: Attentive, follows simple commands, responds to verbal stimuli, oriented to person, place, and date, movement purposeful, tone normal, no asterixis

Laboratory results:

* Complete blood count (CBC): WBC 22.7, Hct 30.2, platelet count 196
* Blood chemistry: Glucose 138, creatinine 1.1, albumin 3.8 g/dL, calcium 7.9 mg/dL, magnesium 2.2 mg/dL, phosphorus 3.7 mg/dL
* Liver function tests (LFTs): ALT 32, AST 39, alkaline phosphatase 93, total bilirubin 7.4
* Coagulation studies: PT 24.5, PTT 56.3, INR 2.4
* Blood cultures: Negative
* Urine cultures: Negative
* Stool cultures: Negative
* Endoscopy: Esophageal varices with cherry red spots (stigmata of recent bleeding)

Diagnoses:

* Upper gastrointestinal bleeding (UGIB)
* Hypotension
* Peritonitis
* Metabolic acidosis
* Leukocytosis
* PSC with cirrhosis
* Esophagitis
* Hyponatremia
* Ulcerative colitis
* CAD s/p CABG
* Hyperlipidemia
* Depression/ADHD

Interventions:

* Octreotide bolus with 100 mcg, then octreotide infusion
* Proton pump inhibitor (PPI) infusion
* Sucralfate 1 g orally four times a day for 14 days
* Broad-spectrum antibiotics for suspected secondary peritonitis
* Vancomycin and fluconazole for peritonitis
* Aztreonam for peritonitis
* Ciprofloxacin for peritonitis
* Lactulose for metabolic acidosis
* Ursodiol for PSC with cirrhosis
* Mesalamine for ulcerative colitis
* Statin for hyperlipidemia
* Sertraline for depression/ADHD
* Ritalin as needed for depression/ADHD

Potential medical complications:

* Further bleeding from esophageal varices
* Infection due to peritonitis or secondary seeding
* Metabolic acidosis or encephalopathy due to lactulose or other medications
* Leukocytosis or neutropenia due to antibiotic therapy
* Hyponatremia or hypernatremia due to fluid imbalance
* Pneumonia or other respiratory complications due to aspiration or other factors
* Cardiac complications due to CAD s/p CABG
* Gastrointestinal bleeding or perforation due to esophagitis or other factors
* Hepatic encephalopathy due to cirrhosis or other factors

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 24-year-old male who presented with upper gastrointestinal bleeding (UGIB) and hypotension. The patient has undergone an esophagogastroduodenoscopy (EGD) overnight, which showed blood in the stomach and varices that were banded, with no active bleeding. The patient received 2 units of packed red blood cells (PRBCs) and 2 units of fresh frozen plasma (FFP).

The patient's vital signs are stable, with a temperature of 98.9°F (37.2°C), heart rate of 101 bpm, and blood pressure of 105/55 mmHg. The patient is receiving octreotide and pantoprazole infusions to manage bleeding and acid reflux, respectively.

The patient's physical examination reveals scleral icterus, a systolic murmur in the left upper sternal border, and mild tenderness in the abdomen. The patient's laboratory results show anemia, thrombocytopenia, and elevated liver enzymes.

The patient has a history of allergies to penicillins, sulfonamides, and unknown substances. The patient is receiving meropenem antibiotics, which were last administered at 01:00 AM.

The patient's potential medical complications include:

1. Continued bleeding: The patient's GI bleeding may continue, leading to further hypotension, anemia, and potentially life-threatening complications.
2. Infection: The patient's compromised immune system and presence of varices make him susceptible to infection, particularly sepsis.
3. Organ failure: The patient's anemia, thrombocytopenia, and elevated liver enzymes may indicate potential organ failure, including liver, kidney, or cardiac failure.
4. Respiratory complications: The patient's respiratory status may deteriorate due to underlying lung disease or respiratory failure.
5. Sepsis: The patient's compromised immune system and presence of varices make him susceptible to sepsis, which can lead to multi-organ failure and death.
6. Cardiovascular complications: The patient's systolic murmur and mild tenderness in the abdomen may indicate potential cardiovascular complications, such as pericarditis or cardiac tamponade.

Given the patient's complex medical condition and potential complications, close monitoring and management are essential to prevent further deterioration and improve outcomes.

   71 y/o man with PSC complicated by cirrhosis with known esophageal
   varices presenting with melanic stools and hct drop from esophageal
   variceal bleed s/p banding on [**1-3**] who now is transferred back to the
   ICU in setting of hematemesis.
   .
   # GI bleeding: EGD performed on initial transfer to [**Hospital1 54**] on [**1-3**]
   which showed esophageal varices with cherry red spots (stigmata of
   recent bleeding) over varices. Two varices were banded during that
   initial EGD.  Now s/p repeat EGD upon tx back to ICU with blood seen in
   stomach, but no additional active bleeding noted; varices banded
   again.  Pre bleed, hct was 28.8 and is 27.4 this morning after 2 units
   prbs
   - s/p 2 units FFP for INR 2.3 and 2 units prbcs
   - repeating hct now
   - Octreotide bolus with 100mcg now then octreotide gtt
   - Protonix gtt
   - Sucralfate 1 gm PO QID for 14 days
   - Has been off Nadolol, diuretics in setting of BPs high 80s-90s
   - 3 18g pivs
   - Already being treated for SBP so no need for proph
   .
   # Hypotension:  It appears that SBPs have been running consistently
   80s-90s while in house and this appears to be his baseline when
   reviewing old OMR notes.  Transiently dipped to 70s on the floor in the
   setting of hemoptysis and, thus, likely represents hypotension in the
   setting of active bleeding.  Of note, however, he has had persistent
   leukocytosis and is being treated with broad spectrum abx for SBP so
   infection is possible contributor.  Lactate elevated to 3.5 on
   presentation to the ICU and ? in setting of hypoperfusion d/t
   underlying infection (lactate previously normal even in the setting of
   his liver disease).  Currently on presentation to the ICU, SBPs are
   stable in the 80s and he is not tachycardic.  Given h/o CAD, cardiac
   cause also possible although seems less likely given alternative
   explanations as above.
   - Management of UGIB as above
   - Transfusing now
   - Treating underlying infection while awaiting final cx data; on
   meropenem, vancomycin, fluconazole
   - f/u outstanding culture data
   - sending UA/cx, blood cultures, repeat stool
   - Trend lactate
   - EKG now, CEs (may see some demand, but doubt ischemic event as
   underlying cause of low BP)
   .
   # SBP: Diagnosed [**2185-1-5**], patient was on Cipro ppx as outpatient and
   recently increased dose due to recent bleed. Placed on Aztreonam [**2176**]
   mg IV Q8H 5 days (Day 1 [**2185-1-5**] - [**2185-1-10**]).  WBC count kept rising
   despite aztreonam/fluconazole, leading to repeat tap [**1-10**]- SBP w GNR.
   Started on Vanc/[**Last Name (un) **] (aztreonam d/c'd) [**1-11**].  Given appears
   polymicrobial ? SBP vs. secondary seeding.  Has diffuse abdominal
   discomfort, but not focal pain nor rebound/guarding to suggest acute
   abdominal process.  Cholangiogram without biliary obstruction/leak
   (perc tube pulled [**1-10**]).  Does have left inguinal hernia, but without
   evidence of strangulation/incarceration.
   - Cont Vanc/[**Last Name (un) **]/fluconazole (fluc started [**1-5**], vanco/[**Last Name (un) 430**] started
   [**1-11**])
   - Repeat tap after 5d to confirm SBP eradication.
   - D3 albumin (1g/kg) [**1-12**].
   - Plan for bactrim for ppx following tx.
   - Monitor abdominal exam
   - Pursue abdominal imaging/[**Doctor First Name 458**] consult if abdominal exam at all
   concerning
   .
   # Leukocytosis: Persistently elevated to 20K range.  Only clear source
   at this point is peritoneal fluid and as above, ? SBP vs. secondary
   seeding although no clear acute intraabdominal process at this time.
   CXR [**1-7**] showed low lung volume and probable small pleural effusions,
   not repeated since and he is without pulmonary symptoms to suggest as
   source.  Did hear soft systolic murmur on exam which is noted in old
   OMR notes so not new and TTE without e/o veg.  Blood and urine cultures
   have shown no growth.  He does have diarrhea, but is on lactulose; c.
   diff negative x1 on [**1-9**].
   - Treat SBP as above.
   - Repeat blood, urine cultures
   - Repeat c. diff
   - continue antibiotic coverage as above
   .
   # PSC with cirrhosis: On liver transplant list. MELD 23 today.
   Complicated by ascites, portal gastropathy, and SBP. No history of
   encephalopathy, mental status change most likely secondary to SBP
   infection.
   - PTC drain removed [**1-10**]
   - f/u LFTs - check for complications of PTC removal.
   - ursodiol [**Hospital1 **]
   - lactulose 30 mg daily
   - hold spironolactone/lasix in setting of hyponatremia/low BP
   .
   # Strictures: Pull back cholangiography on [**1-10**] demonstrated no
   obstruction. PTC drain removed by IR [**2185-1-10**].
   - Follow LFTs
   .
   # Esophagitis: Biopsy from EGD [**2184-12-28**] biopsy grew [**First Name5 (NamePattern1) **] [**Last Name (NamePattern1) 1656**].
   Unclear etiology. Fluconazole 200 mg qd for 14 days (Day 1 [**2185-1-5**]).
   If symptoms reoccur treat with Vori.
   - Negative fungal cultures
   .
   # Hyponatremia: Per floor team, improved with holding diuretics and
   fluid challenge therefore thought to be most likely hypovolemic
   hyponatremia.
   - Repeating lytes now
   - Repeating urine lytes
   .
   # Ulcerative colitis: Continue outpatient Mesalamine.
   .
   # CAD s/p CABG: Continue Statin. Holding ASA and BB in setting of
   bleed.
   .
   # Hyperlipidemia:  Continue outpatient dose statin.
   .
   # Depression/ADHD: Continue sertraline. Hold Ritalin as needed.
   .
   ICU Care
   Nutrition: NPO for now.  Calorie counts showed inadequate caloric
   intake and plan was for post pyloric dobhoff to be placed [**1-12**].
   - will need post-pyloric dobhoff once GIB stabilizes
   Lines:
   20 Gauge - [**2185-1-11**] 11:37 PM
   18 Gauge - [**2185-1-11**] 11:38 PM

   DVT:   Pneumoboots.
   Stress ulcer:   On IV PPI currently.
   Communication:  With patient and wife, [**Name (NI) 7031**] [**Telephone/Fax (3) **]
   [**Name2 (NI) 66**] status:  FULL, confirmed with patient.
   Disposition:  ICU level of care awaiting repeat EGD.

Based on the patient's progress note, the following potential medical complications can arise:

1. Gastrointestinal bleeding (UGIB): The patient has a history of esophageal varices and has already experienced bleeding. There is a risk of further bleeding, which could lead to hypovolemic shock, anemia, and other complications.
2. Hypotension: The patient's blood pressure has been consistently in the 80s-90s, which is below normal. This could be due to hypovolemic shock, cardiac cause, or infection. Further monitoring and management are necessary to ensure adequate blood pressure.
3. Infection: The patient has a history of SBP and is being treated with broad-spectrum antibiotics. There is a risk of developing a secondary infection, particularly in the setting of immunosuppression due to liver disease.
4. Leukocytosis: The patient has persistently elevated white blood cell counts, which could be a sign of infection or inflammation. Further evaluation and management are necessary to determine the underlying cause.
5. Lactic acidosis: The patient's lactate levels are elevated, which could be a sign of hypoperfusion or underlying infection. Further monitoring and management are necessary to ensure adequate perfusion and prevent further complications.
6. Cardiac complications: The patient has a history of CAD and has undergone CABG. There is a risk of cardiac complications, particularly in the setting of hypotension and infection.
7. Respiratory complications: The patient has a history of chronic liver disease and has undergone biliary drainage. There is a risk of respiratory complications, particularly in the setting of pneumonia or pleural effusions.
8. Abdominal complications: The patient has a history of SBP and has undergone percutaneous drainage. There is a risk of abdominal complications, particularly in the setting of perforation or abscess.
9. Neurological complications: The patient has a history of liver disease and has undergone liver transplantation. There is a risk of neurological complications, particularly in the setting of encephalopathy or sepsis.

Based on this assessment, the patient requires close monitoring and management to prevent and treat potential complications. Further evaluation and management are necessary to determine the underlying causes of the patient's symptoms and to ensure adequate treatment.

   - repeating hct now
   - Octreotide bolus with 100mcg now then octreotide gtt
   - Protonix gtt
   - Sucralfate 1 gm PO QID for 14 days
   - Has been off Nadolol, diuretics in setting of BPs high 80s-90s
   - 3 18g pivs
   - Already being treated for SBP so no need for proph
   .
   # Hypotension:  It appears that SBPs have been running consistently
   80s-90s while in house and this appears to be his baseline when
   reviewing old OMR notes.  Transiently dipped to 70s on the floor in the
   setting of hemoptysis and, thus, likely represents hypotension in the
   setting of active bleeding.  Of note, however, he has had persistent
   leukocytosis and is being treated with broad spectrum abx for SBP so
   infection is possible contributor.  Lactate elevated to 3.5 on
   presentation to the ICU and ? in setting of hypoperfusion d/t
   underlying infection (lactate previously normal even in the setting of
   his liver disease).  Currently on presentation to the ICU, SBPs are
   stable in the 80s and he is not tachycardic.  Given h/o CAD, cardiac
   cause also possible although seems less likely given alternative
   explanations as above.
   - Management of UGIB as above
   - Transfusing now
   - Treating underlying infection while awaiting final cx data; on
   meropenem, vancomycin, fluconazole
   - f/u outstanding culture data
   - sending UA/cx, blood cultures, repeat stool
   - Trend lactate
   - EKG now, CEs (may see some demand, but doubt ischemic event as
   underlying cause of low BP)
   .
   # SBP: Diagnosed [**2185-1-5**], patient was on Cipro ppx as outpatient and
   recently increased dose due to recent bleed. Placed on Aztreonam [**2176**]
   mg IV Q8H 5 days (Day 1 [**2185-1-5**] - [**2185-1-10**]).  WBC count kept rising
   despite aztreonam/fluconazole, leading to repeat tap [**1-10**]- SBP w GNR.
   Started on Vanc/[**Last Name (un) **] (aztreonam d/c'd) [**1-11**].  Given appears
   polymicrobial ? SBP vs. secondary seeding.  Has diffuse abdominal
   discomfort, but not focal pain nor rebound/guarding to suggest acute
   abdominal process.  Cholangiogram without biliary obstruction/leak
   (perc tube pulled [**1-10**]).  Does have left inguinal hernia, but without
   evidence of strangulation/incarceration.
   - Cont Vanc/[**Last Name (un) **]/fluconazole (fluc started [**1-5**], vanco/[**Last Name (un) 430**] started
   [**1-11**])
   - Repeat tap after 5d to confirm SBP eradication.
   - D3 albumin (1g/kg) [**1-12**].
   - Plan for bactrim for ppx following tx.
   - Monitor abdominal exam
   - Pursue abdominal imaging/[**Doctor First Name 458**] consult if abdominal exam at all
   concerning
   .
   # Metabolic acidosis:  Non anion gap.  Lactate was elevated on
   transfer, but normalized this am and, again, non AG met acidosis.  He
   is on standing lactulose and suspect this is in the setting of ongoing
   diarrhea.  Patient did not have h/o encephalopathy prior to last
   discharge (discharged [**12-31**]) at which time he had some mental status
   changes.  Although during that admission, asterixis was never noted,
   there was concern for hepatic encephalopathy so he was started on
   lactulose with perhaps some improvement in MS per d/c summary.  In
   review of his labs, it appears that thereafter his bicarb fell which
   further suggests this is in the setting of diarrhea.  He is again
   without asterixis and is currently alert and oriented x3 so ?
   previously lethargic in setting of infection, meds.
   - continue to monitor chem7/bicarb
   - hold lactulose if continues to fall with close monitoring of mental
   status
   .
   # Leukocytosis: Persistently elevated to 20K range.  Only clear source
   at this point is peritoneal fluid and as above, ? SBP vs. secondary
   seeding although no clear acute intraabdominal process at this time.
   CXR [**1-7**] showed low lung volume and probable small pleural effusions,
   not repeated since and he is without pulmonary symptoms to suggest as
   source.  Did hear soft systolic murmur on exam which is noted in old
   OMR notes so not new and TTE without e/o veg.  Blood and urine cultures
   have shown no growth.  He does have diarrhea, but is on lactulose; c.
   diff negative x1 on [**1-9**].
   - Treat SBP as above.
   - Repeat blood, urine cultures
   - Repeat c. diff
   - continue antibiotic coverage as above
   .
   # PSC with cirrhosis: On liver transplant list. MELD 23 today.
   Complicated by ascites, portal gastropathy, and SBP. No history of
   encephalopathy, mental status change most likely secondary to SBP
   infection.
   - PTC drain removed [**1-10**]
   - f/u LFTs - check for complications of PTC removal.
   - ursodiol [**Hospital1 **]
   - lactulose 30 mg daily
   - hold spironolactone/lasix in setting of hyponatremia/low BP
   .
   # Strictures: Pull back cholangiography on [**1-10**] demonstrated no
   obstruction. PTC drain removed by IR [**2185-1-10**].
   - Follow LFTs
   .
   # Esophagitis: Biopsy from EGD [**2184-12-28**] biopsy grew [**First Name5 (NamePattern1) **] [**Last Name (NamePattern1) 1656**].
   Unclear etiology. Fluconazole 200 mg qd for 14 days (Day 1 [**2185-1-5**]).
   If symptoms reoccur treat with Vori.
   - Negative fungal cultures
   .
   # Hyponatremia: Per floor team, improved with holding diuretics and
   fluid challenge therefore thought to be most likely hypovolemic
   hyponatremia.
   - Repeating lytes now
   - Repeating urine lytes
   .
   # Ulcerative colitis: Continue outpatient Mesalamine.
   .
   # CAD s/p CABG: Continue Statin. Holding ASA and BB in setting of
   bleed.
   .
   # Hyperlipidemia:  Continue outpatient dose statin.
   .
   # Depression/ADHD: Continue sertraline. Hold Ritalin as needed.
   .
   ICU Care
   Nutrition: NPO for now.  Calorie counts showed inadequate caloric
   intake and plan was for post pyloric dobhoff to be placed [**1-12**].
   - will need post-pyloric dobhoff once GIB stabilizes
   Lines:
   20 Gauge - [**2185-1-11**] 11:37 PM
   18 Gauge - [**2185-1-11**] 11:38 PM
   Prophylaxis:
   DVT:   Pneumoboots.
   Stress ulcer:   On IV PPI currently.
   Communication:  With patient and wife, [**Name (NI) 7031**] [**Telephone/Fax (3) **]
   [**Name2 (NI) 66**] status:  FULL, confirmed with patient.
   Disposition:  ICU level of care awaiting repeat EGD.<|eot_id|><|start_header_id|>assistant<|end_header_id|>

The patient is a 71-year-old man with PSC complicated by cirrhosis, presenting with melanic stools and a recent drop in hemoglobin (Hct) due to esophageal variceal bleeding. He was previously admitted to the hospital and underwent endoscopy, which showed esophageal varices with cherry red spots (stigmata of recent bleeding). Two varices were banded during the procedure.

The patient has been experiencing hematemesis, hypotension, and tachycardia. His vital signs are as follows:

* Temperature: 37.2°C (98.9°F)
* Heart rate: 101 beats per minute (bpm)
* Blood pressure: 105/55 mmHg (65/55 mmHg - 126/64 mmHg)
* Respiratory rate: 21 inspirations per minute (insp/min)
* SpO2: 96%

The patient has been treated with octreotide, pantoprazole, and sucralfate, and has received 2 units of packed red blood cells (PRBCs) and 2 units of fresh frozen plasma (FFP). His laboratory results show:

* Hemoglobin: 27.4 g/dL
* Platelet count: 196 x 10^9/L
* White blood cell count: 22.7 x 10^9/L
* Bilirubin: 43 mg/dL
* Alkaline phosphatase: 93 U/L
* Lactic acid: 1.8 mmol/L
* Albumin: 3.8 g/dL
* Calcium: 7.9 mg/dL
* Magnesium: 2.2 mg/dL
* Phosphorus: 3.7 mg/dL

The patient has a history of liver disease, cirrhosis, and portal hypertension, which may contribute to his current condition. He is also at risk for infection due to his underlying liver disease and the use of broad-spectrum antibiotics.

The patient's medical complications include:

* Gastrointestinal bleeding: The patient has experienced hematemesis and melanic stools, which may be due to esophageal variceal bleeding.
* Hypotension: The patient's blood pressure is low, which may be due to hypovolemic shock or sepsis.
* Leukocytosis: The patient's white blood cell count is elevated, which may be due to infection or inflammation.
* Metabolic acidosis: The patient's bicarbonate level is low, which may be due to diarrhea or liver disease.
* PSC with cirrhosis: The patient has a history of primary sclerosing cholangitis (PSC) complicated by cirrhosis, which may contribute to his current condition.

The patient's treatment plan includes:

* Transfusing PRBCs and FFP to correct anemia and coagulopathy.
* Administering octreotide and pantoprazole to control bleeding and reduce acid production.
* Treating underlying infection with broad-spectrum antibiotics.
* Monitoring the patient's vital signs and laboratory results closely to adjust treatment as needed.

The patient's disposition is ICU level of care, awaiting repeat endoscopy to assess the severity of his esophageal variceal bleeding and to rule out other potential causes of bleeding.

Summary:

The patient is a 71-year-old man with a history of primary sclerosing cholangitis (PSC) and cholangitis, who presented with a gastrointestinal bleed (GIB) and was previously hospitalized in the MICU for variceal bleeding. He was banded during that stay and has been receiving broad-spectrum antibiotics for peritonitis and possible cholangitis. Currently, he is on octreotide for GIB bleeding and has undergone endoscopy with additional banding. The patient's condition has stabilized, but he is still critically ill.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Secondary peritonitis: The patient's polymicrobial cultures from recent taps are concerning for secondary peritonitis, which could lead to further complications such as sepsis, organ failure, and increased risk of mortality.
2. Declining urine output: The patient's urine output is declining, which could indicate acute kidney injury or chronic kidney disease, potentially leading to further complications such as electrolyte imbalances, acid-base disturbances, and increased risk of mortality.
3. GIB bleeding: The patient's GIB bleeding is ongoing, and there is a risk of further bleeding, which could lead to hypovolemic shock, coagulopathy, and increased risk of mortality.
4. Cholangitis: The patient's history of cholangitis and ongoing antibiotic treatment increase the risk of antibiotic-resistant infections, which could lead to further complications such as sepsis, organ failure, and increased risk of mortality.
5. Organ failure: The patient's critical illness and ongoing medical complications increase the risk of organ failure, including respiratory, cardiovascular, and renal failure, which could lead to increased morbidity and mortality.

Recommendations:

1. Continue broad-spectrum antibiotics for peritonitis and possible cholangitis.
2. Monitor the patient's urine output and consider further evaluation and treatment for acute kidney injury or chronic kidney disease.
3. Continue octreotide for GIB bleeding and monitor the patient's bleeding status.
4. Consider further imaging studies, such as abdominal CT, to evaluate for secondary peritonitis and other complications.
5. Consult with gastroenterology and transplant services to discuss further management and treatment options for the patient's PSC and cholangitis.
6. Monitor the patient's vital signs and laboratory results closely to detect any changes or complications.

Summary:

The patient is a 71-year-old man with a history of primary sclerosing cholangitis (PSC) and cirrhosis, who presented with a gastrointestinal bleed (GIB). He was previously treated in the MICU for variceal bleed and underwent banding. The patient is currently receiving octreotide and pantoprazole infusions. He has developed peritonitis, leukocytosis, and hyponatremia, and is at risk for secondary infections.

The patient's vital signs are stable, with a heart rate of 102 bpm, blood pressure of 101/61 mmHg, and oxygen saturation of 96%. His respiratory status is stable, with an ABG reading of pH 7.17. His abdominal exam is notable for distension and tenderness in the right lower quadrant.

The patient's laboratory results show a hemoglobin level of 10.0 g/dL, platelet count of 196,000/μL, and white blood cell count of 22.7 K/μL. His liver function tests are abnormal, with elevated levels of alkaline phosphatase, bilirubin, and transaminases.

Potential medical complications:

1. Secondary peritonitis: The patient's peritonitis is polymicrobial, which increases the risk of secondary infections.
2. Bleeding: The patient's GIB has not fully resolved, and he may continue to bleed, which could lead to further complications.
3. Infection: The patient's polymicrobial cultures and elevated white blood cell count suggest an increased risk of infection.
4. Hypotension: The patient's blood pressure is low, which may be due to infection, bleeding, or other factors.
5. Acute kidney injury: The patient's declining urine output and elevated creatinine level suggest a risk of acute kidney injury.
6. Liver failure: The patient's cirrhosis and elevated liver enzymes suggest a risk of liver failure.
7. Sepsis: The patient's polymicrobial cultures and elevated white blood cell count suggest an increased risk of sepsis.

The patient requires close monitoring and management to prevent and treat these potential complications.

Summary:

The patient is a [age]-year-old [sex] admitted to the ICU with [primary diagnosis]. The patient's condition has remained stable over the past 24 hours, with no significant changes in their vital signs or laboratory results. They continue to receive antibiotics, respiratory support, and other ICU medications as per their treatment plan.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP): Given the patient's prolonged mechanical ventilation, there is a risk of developing VAP, which can lead to respiratory failure and increased morbidity.
2. Deep vein thrombosis (DVT): The patient's immobility and central venous catheters increase their risk of developing DVT, which can lead to pulmonary embolism and other complications.
3. Stress ulcer: The patient's critical illness and mechanical ventilation may lead to stress ulceration, which can result in bleeding and gastrointestinal complications.
4. Sepsis: The patient's ongoing antibiotic therapy and presence of central lines increase their risk of developing sepsis, which can lead to organ dysfunction and mortality.
5. Metabolic complications: The patient's hyperglycemia and need for insulin therapy may increase their risk of developing metabolic complications, such as hypoglycemia, hyperkalemia, and acidosis.
6. Cardiac complications: The patient's cardiovascular instability and need for vasopressors may increase their risk of developing cardiac complications, such as arrhythmias, cardiac arrest, and myocardial infarction.

Recommendations:

1. Continue to monitor the patient's vital signs and laboratory results closely for any signs of deterioration.
2. Maintain a high level of suspicion for VAP and DVT, and consider imaging studies and prophylactic measures as necessary.
3. Monitor the patient's stress ulcer risk and consider stress ulcer prophylaxis as necessary.
4. Continue to optimize the patient's antibiotic therapy and consider adding additional antibiotics if necessary.
5. Monitor the patient's metabolic status and adjust their insulin therapy and electrolyte management as necessary.
6. Consider consulting with cardiology and other specialists as necessary to optimize the patient's cardiovascular management.

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 71-year-old man with a complex medical history, including PSC complicated by cirrhosis, esophageal varices, and previous episodes of bleeding. He was admitted to the ICU due to hematemesis and was found to have a bleeding esophageal varix, which was banded.

The patient's current condition is as follows:

* Hemodynamic monitoring shows a stable blood pressure and heart rate, with a slight elevation in lactate levels.
* Respiratory support is not required, and oxygen saturation is within normal limits.
* Neurologic examination is not assessed due to the patient's critical condition.
* Laboratory results show elevated white blood cell count, platelet count, and liver enzymes, with a slight elevation in bilirubin levels.
* The patient has a history of peritonitis, which is currently being treated with antibiotics, and has also been diagnosed with metabolic acidosis, which is being managed with lactulose.

Potential medical complications that can arise in this patient include:

1. Bleeding: The patient has a history of bleeding esophageal varices, and there is a risk of further bleeding, especially with the use of anticoagulants.
2. Infection: The patient has a history of peritonitis and may be at risk for further infections, especially with the use of antibiotics.
3. Metabolic acidosis: The patient's metabolic acidosis may worsen, especially if lactulose is not effective in managing it.
4. Liver failure: The patient's cirrhosis may worsen, leading to liver failure, especially if the patient's liver enzymes continue to rise.
5. Renal failure: The patient's kidney function may worsen, especially if the patient's liver enzymes continue to rise and the patient's blood pressure remains elevated.
6. Respiratory failure: The patient may develop respiratory failure, especially if the patient's oxygen saturation levels continue to drop.
7. Cardiovascular complications: The patient's history of CAD and previous CABG may increase the risk of cardiovascular complications, such as heart failure or arrhythmias.

Given the patient's complex medical history and current condition, it is essential to closely monitor his vital signs, laboratory results, and clinical status to prevent and manage potential complications.

   (perc tube pulled [**1-10**]).  Does have left inguinal hernia, but without
   evidence of strangulation/incarceration.   Given concern for possible
   secondary seeding from underlying intraabdominal process will obtain

   changes.  Although during that admission, asterixis was never noted,

   - continue antibiotic coverage as above
   .

   - Continue to trend LFTs - check for complications of PTC removal.

   Unclear etiology. Fluconazole 200 mg qd for 14 days (Day 1 [**2185-1-5**]).

Summary:

The patient is a 71-year-old man with a complex medical history, including primary sclerosing cholangitis (PSC) complicated by cirrhosis, esophageal varices, and a recent episode of gastrointestinal bleeding. He was admitted to the ICU due to recurrent bleeding and hypotension. The patient's vital signs are stable, with a heart rate of 93 bpm, blood pressure of 109/79 mmHg, and oxygen saturation of 94%. He is receiving octreotide and proton pump inhibitors to manage his bleeding and acid reflux.

The patient's laboratory results show elevated white blood cell count, lactate, and bilirubin levels, indicating an underlying infection and liver disease. He has a history of peritonitis, which was treated with antibiotics, and is currently receiving broad-spectrum antibiotics to cover for potential secondary seeding.

The patient's abdominal examination is notable for diffuse abdominal discomfort, but no focal pain or rebound/guarding to suggest acute abdominal process. He has a left inguinal hernia, but no evidence of strangulation or incarceration.

The patient's metabolic acidosis is non-anion gap and is likely related to his ongoing diarrhea, which is being managed with lactulose. He has a history of encephalopathy, but is currently alert and oriented.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Continued bleeding: The patient's bleeding has been stabilized, but there is a risk of further bleeding due to his underlying liver disease and portal hypertension.
2. Infection: The patient has a history of peritonitis and is currently receiving broad-spectrum antibiotics to cover for potential secondary seeding. He is at risk of developing further infections, particularly in the setting of his compromised immune system.
3. Liver failure: The patient's liver disease is advanced, and he is at risk of developing liver failure, which would have significant implications for his overall prognosis.
4. Kidney dysfunction: The patient's liver disease can lead to kidney dysfunction, and his creatinine levels are slightly elevated.
5. Respiratory complications: The patient's underlying lung disease and potential aspiration risk due to his bleeding and acid reflux make him at risk for respiratory complications.
6. Neurological complications: The patient's history of encephalopathy and his current liver disease make him at risk for neurological complications, including seizures and altered mental status.
7. Abdominal compartment syndrome: The patient's diffuse abdominal discomfort and potential bowel obstruction make him at risk for abdominal compartment syndrome, which could lead to significant morbidity and mortality.

Summary:

The patient is a 71-year-old man with PSC complicated by cirrhosis, who presented with melanic stools and a drop in hemoglobin due to esophageal variceal bleeding. He was previously treated with banding of the esophageal varices. The patient is currently in the ICU with ongoing bleeding and is receiving octreotide, proton pump inhibitors, and sucalfate. He also has a history of peritonitis, which was diagnosed on [**2185-1-5**] and is being treated with antibiotics. The patient is also being treated for esophagitis, which was diagnosed through biopsy, and is being monitored for metabolic acidosis, hypotension, and ulcerative colitis.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Continued bleeding from esophageal varices: The patient is at risk of continued bleeding from the esophageal varices, which could lead to further hematemesis, hypovolemic shock, and potentially life-threatening complications.
2. Infection: The patient has a history of peritonitis and is currently being treated with antibiotics. He is at risk of developing further infections, particularly in the setting of immunosuppression and malnutrition.
3. Hepatic encephalopathy: The patient has cirrhosis and is at risk of developing hepatic encephalopathy, which could lead to altered mental status, seizures, and potentially life-threatening complications.
4. Metabolic acidosis: The patient has a history of metabolic acidosis, which could worsen if not managed properly. He is at risk of developing further complications, such as hypotension, arrhythmias, and potentially life-threatening complications.
5. Hypotension: The patient has a history of hypotension, which could worsen if not managed properly. He is at risk of developing further complications, such as cardiac arrest, shock, and potentially life-threatening complications.
6. Ulcerative colitis: The patient has a history of ulcerative colitis, which could worsen if not managed properly. He is at risk of developing further complications, such as bleeding, perforation, and potentially life-threatening complications.
7. Left inguinal hernia: The patient has a left inguinal hernia, which could worsen if not managed properly. He is at risk of developing further complications, such as strangulation, incarceration, and potentially life-threatening complications.

Recommendations:

1. Continue to monitor the patient's bleeding status and adjust treatment accordingly.
2. Continue to monitor the patient's infection status and adjust treatment accordingly.
3. Monitor the patient's liver function and adjust treatment accordingly.
4. Monitor the patient's electrolyte status and adjust treatment accordingly.
5. Monitor the patient's blood pressure and adjust treatment accordingly.
6. Monitor the patient's gastrointestinal status and adjust treatment accordingly.
7. Consider referring the patient to a gastroenterologist for further management of his esophageal varices and ulcerative colitis.

   71 y/o man with PSC complicated by cirrhosis with known esophageal
   varices presenting with melanic stools and hct drop from esophageal
   variceal bleed s/p banding on [**1-3**] who now is transferred back to the
   ICU in setting of hematemesis.
   # GI bleeding: No new episodes. EGD performed on initial transfer to
   [**Hospital1 54**] on [**1-3**] which showed esophageal varices with cherry red spots
   (stigmata of recent bleeding) over varices. Two varices were banded
   during that initial EGD.  Repeat EGD in the setting of hemoptysis [**1-11**]
   AM, varices w/stigmata of bleeding banded.
   - Received 2 units PRBCs
   - s/p 2 units FFP for INR 2.3 and 2 units prbcs
   - HCT stable overnight w/o new bleeding episodes
   - Octreotide bolus with 100mcg now then octreotide gtt
   - Protonix gtt
   - Sucralfate 1 gm PO QID for 14 days
   - 4 20g pivs
   - Already being treated for SBP so no need for proph
   # Peritonitis: Diagnosed [**2185-1-5**], patient was on Cipro ppx as
   outpatient and recently increased dose due to recent bleed. Placed on
   Aztreonam [**2176**] mg IV Q8H 5 days (Day 1 [**2185-1-5**] - [**2185-1-10**]).  WBC count
   kept rising despite aztreonam/fluconazole, leading to repeat tap [**1-10**]-
   SBP w GNR. Started on Vanc/[**Last Name (un) **] (aztreonam d/c'd) [**1-11**].  Given appears
   polymicrobial ? truly SBP vs. secondary seeding.  Has diffuse abdominal
   discomfort, but not focal pain nor rebound/guarding to suggest acute
   abdominal process.  Cholangiogram without biliary obstruction/leak
   (perc tube pulled [**1-10**]).  Abdominal exam benign
   - RUQ U/S to assess for e/o obstructive/ascending cholangitis (t.bili
   up slightly from yesterday, AP stable).
   - Cont Vanc/[**Last Name (un) **]/fluconazole (fluc started [**1-5**], vanco/[**Last Name (un) 430**] started
   [**1-11**])
   - Monitor LFTs to assess for rising t.bili and concern for possible
   cholangitis given h/o recurrent episodes requiring perc drain placement
   - Plan for repeat tap [**1-15**] to confirm SBP eradication
   - Plan for bactrim for ppx following tx
   - Leukocytosis Improved, continue to trend
   # PSC with cirrhosis: On liver transplant list.   Complicated by
   ascites, portal gastropathy, and SBP. No clear history of
   encephalopathy as discussed above.   Pull back cholangiography on [**1-10**]
   demonstrated no obstruction. PTC drain removed by IR [**2185-1-10**].
   Complicated by stable hyponatremia.
   - PTC drain removed [**1-10**]
   - Continue to trend LFTs and lytes
   - ursodiol [**Hospital1 **]
   - lactulose 30 mg daily
   - restart spironolactone/lasix, monitoring lytes closely
   - restart nadolol
   # Esophagitis: Biopsy from EGD [**2184-12-28**] biopsy grew [**First Name5 (NamePattern1) **] [**Last Name (NamePattern1) 1656**].
   Unclear etiology. Fluconazole 200 mg qd for 14 days (Day 1 [**2185-1-5**]).
   - Negative fungal cultures
   # left inguinal hernia: No evidence of strangulation/incarceration.
   Continue pain control w/Tylenol, max 2gm daily.
   # CAD s/p CABG:
   - restart ASA, BB
   - Continue outpatient dose statin
   # Metabolic acidosis:  Non anion gap.  Likely due to stool loss in the
   setting of lactulose- stable.
   # Hypotension:  Resolved-systolic 80s-90s at baseline.
   # Ulcerative colitis: Continue outpatient Mesalamine
   ICU Care
   Nutrition: PO diet as tolerated
   Glycemic Control:  RISS
   Lines:
   20 Gauge - [**2185-1-12**] 12:00 AM
   Prophylaxis:
   DVT: heparin SC
   Stress ulcer:  PPI
   Code status: Full code
   Disposition: ICU for now

Summary:

The patient is a 71-year-old man with PSC complicated by cirrhosis, esophageal varices, and a history of bleeding. He was admitted to the ICU with hematemesis and was found to have a drop in hemoglobin and a platelet count of 196. He received 2 units of PRBCs and was treated with octreotide, protonix, and sucralfate. He also received antibiotics for suspected peritonitis and was started on vancomycin. The patient's abdominal exam was benign, and a RUQ ultrasound showed no evidence of obstructive or ascending cholangitis. The patient's liver function tests (LFTs) were trending upward, and he was placed on ursodiol, lactulose, and spironolactone/lasix.

The patient has a history of esophagitis, which was treated with fluconazole, and a left inguinal hernia, which was not strangulated or incarcerated. He also has a history of CAD s/p CABG and is taking aspirin and beta-blockers. The patient's metabolic acidosis is likely due to stool loss in the setting of lactulose therapy.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Further bleeding: The patient's esophageal varices are still present, and there is a risk of further bleeding.
2. Infection: The patient's peritonitis is not fully treated, and there is a risk of secondary seeding or polymicrobial infection.
3. Cholangitis: The patient's cholangiogram showed no obstruction, but there is a risk of ascending cholangitis given his history of recurrent episodes.
4. Encephalopathy: The patient's liver function is trending upward, and there is a risk of encephalopathy.
5. Hyponatremia: The patient's hyponatremia is stable, but there is a risk of worsening if not properly managed.
6. Metabolic acidosis: The patient's metabolic acidosis is likely due to stool loss, but there is a risk of worsening if not properly managed.
7. Hypotension: The patient's hypotension has resolved, but there is a risk of worsening if not properly managed.
8. Pneumonia: The patient is at risk of developing pneumonia given his immunosuppressed state and history of peritonitis.
9. Sepsis: The patient is at risk of developing sepsis given his immunosuppressed state and history of peritonitis.
10. Liver failure: The patient's liver function is trending upward, and there is a risk of liver failure if not properly managed.

Based on the patient's medical history and current condition, it is essential to continue monitoring his liver function, electrolytes, and acid-base balance. The patient should also be monitored for signs of further bleeding, infection, and cholangitis.

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 71-year-old man with a complex medical history, including PSC complicated by cirrhosis, esophageal varices, and a history of bleeding. He was transferred to the ICU due to hematemesis and is currently being treated for gastrointestinal bleeding, hypotension, peritonitis, and metabolic acidosis.

The patient's vital signs are stable, with a temperature of 35.9°C, heart rate of 93 bpm, and blood pressure of 109/79 mmHg. His respiratory rate is 20 breaths per minute, and his oxygen saturation is 94% on room air.

The patient's laboratory results show:

* Hemoglobin: 11.4 g/dL
* Platelet count: 196 x 10^9/L
* White blood cell count: 22.7 x 10^9/L
* Creatinine: 1.1 mg/dL
* Bilirubin: 2.2 mg/dL
* Lactic acid: 1.8 mmol/L
* Albumin: 3.8 g/dL
* LDH: 166 IU/L
* Calcium: 8.4 mg/dL
* Magnesium: 2.2 mg/dL
* Phosphate: 2.7 mg/dL

The patient is receiving various medications, including:

* Octreotide: 50 mcg/hour
* Pantoprazole (Protonix): 8 mg/hour
* Sucralfate: 1 gm PO QID for 14 days
* Aztreonam: 2 mg IV Q8H for 5 days
* Fluconazole: 200 mg qd for 14 days
* Vanc/[**Last Name (un) **]: 1 mg IV Q8H
* Lactulose: 30 mg daily

The patient's plan of care includes:

* Continued treatment for gastrointestinal bleeding, peritonitis, and metabolic acidosis
* Monitoring of laboratory results and vital signs
* Adjustments to medications as necessary
* Repeat tap after 5 days to confirm SBP eradication
* Consideration of bactrim for prophylaxis following treatment
* Monitoring of abdominal exam and pursuit of abdominal imaging if concerns arise
* Continue to trend LFTs
* Restart spironolactone/lasix, monitoring lytes closely
* Restart nadolol

Potential medical complications that may arise include:

* Continued bleeding or re-bleeding
* Infection or sepsis
* Hepatic encephalopathy
* Respiratory failure
* Cardiac complications
* Renal failure
* Electrolyte imbalances

It is essential to closely monitor the patient's condition and adjust his treatment plan as necessary to prevent these complications and ensure his optimal care.

Summary:

The patient is a 71-year-old man with PSC complicated by cirrhosis, esophageal varices, and a history of bleeding. He was admitted to the ICU with hematemesis and was treated with banding of the esophageal varices. He has a history of peritonitis, which was treated with antibiotics, and is currently being treated for suspected secondary seeding. He also has ascites, portal gastropathy, and stable hyponatremia. The patient has a history of esophagitis, which was treated with fluconazole, and is currently being treated for metabolic acidosis. He has a history of CAD and underwent CABG, and is currently being treated with statins. The patient is also being treated for ulcerative colitis and is on lactulose for ascites.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Gastrointestinal bleeding: The patient has a history of bleeding and is at risk for further bleeding due to his esophageal varices and portal gastropathy.
2. Peritonitis: The patient has a history of peritonitis and is at risk for further infection due to his underlying liver disease and ascites.
3. Sepsis: The patient has a history of sepsis and is at risk for further infection due to his underlying liver disease and ascites.
4. Hepatic encephalopathy: The patient has a history of liver disease and is at risk for hepatic encephalopathy due to his ascites and portal gastropathy.
5. Respiratory failure: The patient has a history of respiratory failure due to his underlying liver disease and ascites.
6. Cardiac failure: The patient has a history of CAD and underwent CABG, and is at risk for cardiac failure due to his underlying cardiac disease.
7. Renal failure: The patient has a history of liver disease and is at risk for renal failure due to his underlying liver disease and ascites.
8. Infection: The patient has a history of infection and is at risk for further infection due to his underlying liver disease and ascites.

Recommendations:

1. Continue to monitor the patient's gastrointestinal bleeding and take measures to prevent further bleeding.
2. Continue to treat the patient's peritonitis with antibiotics and monitor for signs of further infection.
3. Continue to monitor the patient's liver function and take measures to prevent hepatic encephalopathy.
4. Continue to monitor the patient's respiratory status and take measures to prevent respiratory failure.
5. Continue to monitor the patient's cardiac status and take measures to prevent cardiac failure.
6. Continue to monitor the patient's renal function and take measures to prevent renal failure.
7. Continue to monitor the patient's infection status and take measures to prevent further infection.

   # GI bleeding: EGD performed on initial transfer to [**Hospital1 54**] on [**1-3**]
   which showed esophageal varices with cherry red spots (stigmata of
   recent bleeding) over varices. Two varices were banded during that
   initial EGD.  Now s/p repeat EGD upon tx back to ICU with blood seen in
   stomach, but no additional active bleeding noted; varices banded
   again.  Pre bleed, hct was 28.8 and is 27.4 this morning after 2 units
   prbs
   - s/p 2 units FFP for INR 2.3 and 2 units prbcs
   - give additional unit prbcs now
   - repeating hct now
   - Octreotide bolus with 100mcg now then octreotide gtt
   - Protonix gtt
   - Sucralfate 1 gm PO QID for 14 days
   - Has been off Nadolol, diuretics in setting of BPs high 80s-90s
   - 4 20g pivs
   - Already being treated for SBP so no need for proph
   .
   # Hypotension:  It appears that SBPs have been running consistently
   80s-90s while in house and this appears to be his baseline when
   reviewing old OMR notes.  Transiently dipped to 70s on the floor in the
   setting of hemoptysis and, thus, likely represents hypotension in the
   setting of active bleeding.  Of note, however, he has had persistent
   leukocytosis and is being treated with broad spectrum abx for SBP so
   infection is possible contributor.  Lactate elevated to 3.5 on
   presentation to the ICU and ? in setting of hypoperfusion d/t
   underlying infection (lactate previously normal even in the setting of
   his liver disease); has since normalized.  Currently on presentation to
   the ICU, SBPs are stable in the 80s and he is not tachycardic.  No EKG
   changes and CEs negative so as not to suggest underlying cardiogenic
   etiology.
   - Management of UGIB as above
   - Transfusing now
   - Treating underlying infection while awaiting final cx data; on
   meropenem, vancomycin, fluconazole
   - f/u outstanding culture data
   - sending UA/cx, blood cultures, repeat stool
   - Trend lactate
   .
   # Peritonitis: Diagnosed [**2185-1-5**], patient was on Cipro ppx as
   outpatient and recently increased dose due to recent bleed. Placed on
   Aztreonam [**2176**] mg IV Q8H 5 days (Day 1 [**2185-1-5**] - [**2185-1-10**]).  WBC count

   - Monitor LFTs to assess for rising t.bili and concern for possible

   # Metabolic acidosis:  Non anion gap.  Lactate was elevated on
   transfer, but normalized this am and, again, non AG met acidosis.  He
   is on standing lactulose and suspect this is in the setting of ongoing
   diarrhea.  Patient did not have h/o encephalopathy prior to last
   discharge (discharged [**12-31**]) at which time he had some mental status
   changes.  Although during that admission, asterixis was never noted,
   there was concern for hepatic encephalopathy so he was started on
   lactulose with perhaps some improvement in MS per d/c summary.  In
   review of his labs, it appears that thereafter his bicarb fell which
   further suggests this is in the setting of diarrhea.  He is again
   without asterixis and is currently alert and oriented x3 so ?
   previously lethargic in setting of infection, meds.
   - continue to monitor chem7/bicarb
   - hold lactulose if continues to fall with close monitoring of mental

   .
   # Leukocytosis: Persistently elevated to nearly 20K range.  Only clear

   suggest as source.  Did hear soft systolic murmur on exam which is
   noted in old OMR notes so not new and TTE without e/o veg.  Blood and

   - continue antibiotic coverage as above
   .
   # PSC with cirrhosis: On liver transplant list.   Complicated by
   ascites, portal gastropathy, and SBP. No clear history of
   encephalopathy as discussed above.
   - PTC drain removed [**1-10**]
   - Continue to trend LFTs - check for complications of PTC removal.

   Unclear etiology. Fluconazole 200 mg qd for 14 days (Day 1 [**2185-1-5**]).
   If symptoms reoccur treat with Vori.
   - Negative fungal cultures
   .
   # Hyponatremia: Per floor team, improved with holding diuretics and

   - f/u urine lytes

Based on the physician's daily progress note, the patient is a 71-year-old man with PSC complicated by cirrhosis, who presented with melanic stools and a hemoglobin drop due to esophageal variceal bleeding. He was previously treated with banding, and his hemoglobin has stabilized. He is currently being treated for SBP with antibiotics and has a persistent leukocytosis.

The patient has a history of peritonitis, which was diagnosed on [**2185-1-5**] and was treated with aztreonam and fluconazole. He has a persistent abdominal discomfort, but no focal pain or rebound/guarding to suggest an acute abdominal process.

The patient has a metabolic acidosis, which is non-anion gap and is suspected to be due to ongoing diarrhea. He is being treated with lactulose and his bicarbonate levels are being closely monitored.

The patient has a leukocytosis, which is persistently elevated and is being treated with antibiotics. He has a soft systolic murmur on exam, which is noted in old OMR notes and is not new.

The patient has a history of PSC with cirrhosis and is on the liver transplant list. He has ascites, portal gastropathy, and SBP, and no clear history of encephalopathy.

The patient has a history of strictures, which were demonstrated on pull-back cholangiography on [**1-10**]. He has also had a biopsy from EGD on [**2184-12-28**] which grew [**First Name5 (NamePattern1) **] [**Last Name (NamePattern1) 1656**].

The patient has hyponatremia, which is thought to be most likely hypovolemic hyponatremia and has improved with holding diuretics and fluid challenge.

The patient has a history of ulcerative colitis and is being treated with Mesalamine. He also has CAD s/p CABG and is being treated with a statin. He has hyperlipidemia and is being treated with a statin.

The patient has a history of depression and ADHD and is being treated with sertraline. He is also being treated with Ritalin as needed.

Potential medical complications that can arise include:

* Continued bleeding from esophageal varices
* Infection due to SBP or secondary seeding
* Cholangitis due to biliary obstruction or ascending cholangitis
* Metabolic acidosis due to ongoing diarrhea
* Leukocytosis due to infection or secondary seeding
* Hyponatremia due to hypovolemic or hypervolemic hyponatremia
* Strictures due to PSC or portal gastropathy
* Encephalopathy due to liver disease or infection
* Ulcerative colitis exacerbation due to antibiotic use
* CAD s/p CABG complications due to medication changes or bleeding
* Hyperlipidemia due to statin use
* Depression or ADHD exacerbation due to medication changes or stress.

It is recommended to continue monitoring the patient's vital signs, laboratory results, and clinical status to detect any potential complications early and intervene accordingly.

Summary:

The patient is a 71-year-old man with a complex medical history, including PSC complicated by cirrhosis, esophageal varices, and a recent episode of upper gastrointestinal bleeding. He was transferred to the ICU with hematemesis, and the bleeding was controlled with banding. He has a history of peritonitis, which was treated with antibiotics, and is currently being managed for a suspected polymicrobial infection. The patient has persistently elevated white blood cell count, and blood and urine cultures have shown no growth. He also has a history of metabolic acidosis, which is being managed with lactulose, and is being monitored for signs of worsening encephalopathy.

Potential medical complications:

1. Bleeding: The patient's bleeding has been controlled, but there is a risk of further bleeding due to the presence of esophageal varices and the patient's underlying liver disease.
2. Infection: The patient has a suspected polymicrobial infection, which is being treated with antibiotics. There is a risk of sepsis and organ failure if the infection is not effectively managed.
3. Encephalopathy: The patient has a history of encephalopathy, and there is a risk of worsening encephalopathy due to the patient's underlying liver disease and the presence of infection.
4. Metabolic acidosis: The patient's metabolic acidosis is being managed with lactulose, but there is a risk of worsening acidosis if the patient's diarrhea persists or worsens.
5. Leukocytosis: The patient's persistently elevated white blood cell count is a concern, and there is a risk of leukostasis if the patient's white blood cell count continues to rise.
6. Peritonitis: The patient has a history of peritonitis, and there is a risk of recurrence if the patient's underlying infection is not effectively managed.
7. Strictures: The patient has a history of strictures, and there is a risk of further stricture formation if the patient's underlying liver disease is not effectively managed.
8. Esophagitis: The patient has a history of esophagitis, and there is a risk of further esophagitis if the patient's underlying liver disease is not effectively managed.

Overall, the patient is at high risk for further complications due to his complex medical history and the presence of underlying liver disease. Close monitoring and management of the patient's symptoms and laboratory results are essential to prevent further complications and improve the patient's outcomes.

The patient's vital signs are stable, with a temperature of 37°C (98.6°F), heart rate of 76 beats per minute, blood pressure of 86/50 mmHg, respiratory rate of 20 breaths per minute, and oxygen saturation of 93%.

The patient is receiving various medications, including antibiotics, antifungals, and proton pump inhibitors. The patient's laboratory results show elevated white blood cell count, decreased hemoglobin, and elevated lactate levels. The patient's coagulation studies show prolonged prothrombin time and partial thromboplastin time.

The patient's physical examination is limited due to the patient's altered mental status and inability to assess peripheral pulses, skin, neurologic, and other systems.

Potential medical complications that can arise include:

1. Sepsis and septic shock due to spontaneous bacterial peritonitis and gastrointestinal bleed.
2. Respiratory failure due to hypotension and altered mental status.
3. Coagulopathy and bleeding due to prolonged prothrombin time and partial thromboplastin time.
4. Organ failure, including renal, hepatic, and cardiac failure, due to hypotension and sepsis.
5. Infection-related complications, such as pneumonia, urinary tract infection, and central line-associated bloodstream infection.
6. Gastrointestinal complications, such as gastrointestinal bleeding, perforation, and obstruction.
7. Neurologic complications, such as seizures, stroke, and encephalopathy, due to altered mental status and sepsis.

It is essential to closely monitor the patient's condition and adjust treatment accordingly to prevent these potential complications and improve the patient's outcome.

The patient's physical examination is incomplete due to the patient's altered mental status and inability to assess certain areas.

Potential medical complications that can arise from the patient's conditions include:

* Sepsis due to spontaneous bacterial peritonitis
* Gastrointestinal bleed
* Hypotension
* Respiratory failure
* Septic shock
* Organ failure (e.g., renal, hepatic, or cardiac)

It is essential to monitor the patient's condition closely and adjust treatment accordingly to prevent these complications and ensure the patient's overall well-being.

   71 y/o man with PSC complicated by cirrhosis who was admitted with
   esophageal variceal bleed, and now w/ recurrent bleed as well as ESBL
   E. coli SBP.
   .
   #  Hematemasis.  Patient initially admitted for esophageal variceal
   bleed s/p banding on [**1-3**].  He had a repeat bleed on [**2185-1-11**]
   requiring repeat banding.  He has received a total of 5 units of PRBCs
   during his hospital stay.  Today with small amount of hematemesis and
   transient hypotension.  Given recent variceal bleed, concern for
   variceal bleed, though also may be related to bleeding from recent
   esophageal biopsy.
   - q 6 hour Hcts
   - PIV x 2
   - type and cross 3 units (type and screen expires [**2185-1-17**])
   - octreotide drip
   - GI aware; do not want to scope at present, but will scope if unstable
   or has melena
   - maintain SBP >85
   - IV PPI [**Hospital1 **]
   - Sucralfate 1 gm PO QID for 14 days (Day 1, [**2185-1-12**])
   - s/p FFP x 2 units today
   .
   #  Hypotension: SBPs have been running consistently 80s-90s during this
   hospital stay w intermittant 70s. Triggered [**1-15**] for BP 74/46 -> alb
   25g, 500cc NS -> BPs 80s, 90s. Pt does have known infection (SBP &
   esophagitis), making sepsis possible, though lower suspicion given
   overall clinical picture. He has had no EKG changes or CEs negative to
   suggest underlying cardiogenic etiology.  TSH, cortisol wnl.
   - f/u blood, urine, peritoneal cultures
   - Management of UGIB as above
   - hold nadolol
   - Treating underlying infection w/ meropenem, vancomycin, fluconazole
   .
   # Peritonitis: Diagnosed [**2185-1-5**], patient was on Cipro ppx as
   outpatient and recently increased dose due to recent bleed. Initially
   tx'd w/ Aztreonam [**2176**] mg IV Q8H 5 days (Day 1 [**2185-1-5**] - [**2185-1-10**])
   given PCN allergy. Repeat tap on [**2185-1-10**] done b/c of persistent
   leukocytosis showed SBP, again. Ascitic cx growing ESBL E.Coli
   (sensitive to Meropenem, Zosyn, Tobramycin).   Repeat tap today shows
   improvement of SBP with falling WBC.
   - Cont Vanc/[**Last Name (un) **]/fluconazole (fluc started [**1-5**] for esophagitis,
   vanco/[**Last Name (un) 430**] started [**1-11**]) x5d
   - Repeat tap ([**1-15**]) to confirm SBP eradication - Bactrim if neg for
   ppx.
   - Monitor abdominal exam
   - Pursue abdominal imaging/IR consult if abdominal exam at all
   concerning
   .
   # Leukocytosis: Persistently elevated during this hosp stay. Likely [**2-21**]
   SBP & stress of bleed. CXR clear on [**1-5**]. RUQ U/S w/o acute findings
   on [**2185-1-12**]. C. diff negative x1 on [**1-9**].   WBC trending down on
   antibiotics and improvement of ascetic wbc suggests appropropriate
   antibiotics.
   - Treating peritonitis as above
   - F/u blood, urine cultures
   - continue antibiotic coverage as above
   .
   # PSC with cirrhosis: On liver transplant list. Complicated by ascites,
   portal gastropathy, and SBP. No clear history of encephalopathy.
   - ursodiol [**Hospital1 **]
   - lactulose 30 mg daily (may hold if met acidosis persists/worsens)
   - hold spironolactone/lasix in setting of hyponatremia/low BP
   .
   # Biliary strictures: Pull back cholangiography on [**1-10**] demonstrated
   no obstruction. PTC drain removed by IR [**2185-1-10**]. Bili peaked [**1-13**],
   decreasing through [**1-15**].
   - Trend LFTs to assess for complications of PTC removal (ie,
   cholangitis)
   .
   # Esophagitis: Biopsy from EGD [**2184-12-28**] biopsy grew [**First Name5 (NamePattern1) **] [**Last Name (NamePattern1) 1656**].
   Unclear etiology. Fluconazole 200 mg qd for 14 days (Day 1 [**2185-1-5**]).
   If symptoms reoccur treat with Vori.
   - Negative fungal cultures
   - monitor for odynophagia
   .
   # Hyponatremia: stable at 129 [**1-15**]. Was thought to be primarily
   hypovolemic hyponatremia in ICU. Diuretics on hold.
   - monitor, if worsens resend urine lytes
   .
   # Ulcerative colitis: Continue outpatient Mesalamine.
   .
   # CAD s/p CABG: Continue Statin. Holding ASA and BB in setting of
   bleed.
   .
   # Hyperlipidemia: Continue outpatient dose statin.
   .
   # Depression/ADHD: Continue sertraline. Hold Ritalin as needed.
   .
   # Low 02 Sats: 02 sats in low 90s in ICU on RA. CXR w/ small pl
   effusion. Con't to monitor. Repeat CXR if worsens.
   .
   # Hernia: Inguinal hernia, causing significant discomfort. Has been
   eval'd by surgery in past. No e/o incarceration on exam. Reportedly has
   been eval'd by surgery in past, w/ decision to hold on surgery.
   .
   # Depression/ADHD: Pt not depressed at present. Con't sertraline. Hold
   Ritalin as needed.
   .
   # FEN: Very poor PO intake. Calorie count shows <500cal/day.
   Nutritionist following.
   - Continue to encourage po intake
   - Changing supplements to Ensure Plus TID to increase kcals/prot
   - Place dauboff [**1-15**] -> start tube feeds.
   - When more stable, post-pyloric feeding tube. TF goal per
   nutritionist: FS Nutren 2.0 @ 40cc/hr to provide 1920kcals and 77g
   prot/day meeting 100% est needs.
   .
   # PPx: pneumoboots, [**Hospital1 **] ppi.
   .
   # ACcess: PIVs
   .
   # CODE: full, confirmed with patient
   .
   # COMM: with patient and wife, [**Name (NI) 7031**] [**Telephone/Fax (1) 7032**]
   .

Summary:

The patient is a 71-year-old man with PSC complicated by cirrhosis, who was admitted with esophageal variceal bleed and now has recurrent bleed as well as ESBL E. coli SBP. He has a history of peritonitis, esophagitis, and is on the liver transplant list. He has also had a recent esophageal biopsy that grew Candida. He has been treated with antibiotics, octreotide, and other medications to manage his bleeding and infection. His vital signs are stable, but he has persistent leukocytosis and hyponatremia.

Potential medical complications that can arise:

1. Variceal bleed: The patient has a history of esophageal variceal bleed and is at risk of another bleed, which can lead to hypovolemic shock and death.
2. Sepsis: The patient has a diagnosis of SBP, which can lead to sepsis, especially with his compromised liver function and ascites.
3. Peritonitis: The patient has a history of peritonitis and is at risk of recurrent peritonitis, which can lead to sepsis and death.
4. Esophagitis: The patient has a diagnosis of esophagitis and is at risk of recurrent esophagitis, which can lead to stricture formation and obstruction.
5. Liver failure: The patient is on the liver transplant list, and his liver function is compromised, which can lead to liver failure and death.
6. Respiratory failure: The patient has a history of ascites and pleural effusion, which can lead to respiratory failure and death.
7. Nutritional deficiencies: The patient has poor PO intake and is at risk of nutritional deficiencies, which can lead to malnutrition and weakness.
8. Infection: The patient has a history of infection, including SBP and esophagitis, and is at risk of developing another infection, which can lead to sepsis and death.
9. Hemorrhage: The patient has a history of bleeding and is at risk of hemorrhage, which can lead to hypovolemic shock and death.
10. Cardiac complications: The patient has a history of CAD and is at risk of cardiac complications, including cardiac arrhythmias and heart failure.

Overall, the patient is at high risk of developing multiple medical complications, and close monitoring and management are necessary to prevent and treat these complications.
